entry.title: Top 8 Posts on Network Effects
entry.content:
Network Effects are the most powerful force in business.

They produced some of the most iconic products and companies ever. Examples: WhatsApp, Airbnb, Google, Amazon, Alibaba, Uber, ebay, Facebook, Opentable, WeChat and Twitter.

According to venture capital firm, NFX, network effects are responsible for 70% of the value created by tech companies since the Internet became a thing in 1994 ü§Ø

Here are my favorite posts on Network Effects.

Anu Hariharan on Network Effects

Anu gives the best explanation of the differences between networks, marketplaces and platforms.

  • Network = group of connected users and you‚Äôre sharing information and you‚Äôre trying to drive your product. ( fb, WhatsApp, slack )
  • Marketplace = two heterogeneous sides. So you have two sites, think of Ebay as a marketplace. You have sellers and buyers. Think of Airbnb, you have hosts and guests. ( eBay, airbnb, instacart )
  • Platform = you have users and developers and a platform. And so think of it where both groups, users and developers, help build the platform, it can be programmatic, customized. But each group reinforces the value of each other. ( apple, microsoft, fb )

Andreesen Horowitz on Network Effects

Anu Hariharan and a16z put together an awesome slideshare deck network effects.

10 Factors To Consider When Evaluating Digital Marketplaces

Bill Gurley‚Äôs ‚ÄúAll Markets Are Not Created Equal‚Äù is a legendary post for anyone thinking about building a marketplace.

10 factors to consider when evaluating new marketplace opportunity:

  1. New Experience vs. the Status Quo
  2. Economic Advantages vs. the Status Quo
  3. Opportunity for Technology to Add Value
  4. High Fragmentation
  5. Friction of Supplier Sign-Up
  6. Size of the Market Opportunity
  7. Expand the Market
  8. Frequency
  9. Payment Flow
  10. Network Effects

The NFX of Trulia: Building a $3.5 Billion Marketplace

Pete Flint outlines the building of Trulia‚Äôs network effects.

Our first big challenge, one which every online marketplace must reckon with, was the so-called ‚Äúchicken-and-egg‚Äù problem. How could we attract a consumer audience (homebuyers) without any listings, and how could we attract listings without an audience?

A Dozen Things I‚Äôve Learned about Multi-sided Markets

Trent Giffin‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Dozen Things I‚Äôve Learned about Multi-sided Markets‚Äù is insightful and very easy to digest.

I recommend reading everything Trent writes.

  1. Multi-sided markets bring together two or more interdependent groups who need each other in some way.
  2. A critical difference between single and multi-sided market is that the sides interact directly.
  3. Multi-sided markets are not linear.
  4. A multi-sided market is not valuable if the sides can find each other easily.
  5. ‚ÄúDemand side economies of scale‚Äù result when the value of a product or service changes in a positive way as more people use it.
  6. ‚ÄúSupply side economies of scale‚Äù exist when there are reductions in the average cost per unit associated with increasing the scale of production.
  7. Creating a successful multi-sided market requires that the business overcome the ‚Äúchicken and egg problem.‚Äù
  8. The chicken and egg problem is best overcome if one side is clearly made the loss leader.
  9. The sides of the market should complement each other ‚Äì if the sides are complements, it not only reduces the customer acquisition cost (CAC) but assembles sides that want to to enter into exchanges.
  10. Subsidizing the side of the multi-sided market with lower marginal cost/COGS is optimal.
  11. Businesses that are slow to get to critical mass can run out of cash and momentum.
  12. Clear profit pools should exist.

The Network Effects Manual

The NFX team take Network Effects to a whole new level with ‚ÄúThe Network Effects Manual‚Äù

They list out each type of network effect with a diagram, explanation of properties and example companies.

The Network Effects Bible

The NFX team goes even further with Network Effects by creating ‚ÄúThe Network Effects Bible‚Äù. The post and slideshare are incredibly insightful and a must read for every founder.

Outline

  1. Why Network Effects Are Important
  2. How Networks Work
  3. Properties of Networks
  4. Building and Maintaining Network Effects
  5. Related Concepts

The Kardashian Network Effect

Last but not least, Andrew Chen gives the world a new mental model üòâ

The Kardashian Network Effect - Cross promotion platform built by multiple mutually reinforcing social accounts that cross-promote each other

Network Effects aren‚Äôt just for tech companies.

Originally tweet stormed at @jaymehoffman
entry.summary: Network Effects are the most powerful force in business.

entry.title: Quotes I Live By
entry.content:
What‚Äôs next?: ‚ÄúFigure out what information, people or resource you need in life to get to the next level.‚Äù - Me Goal setting: ‚ÄúGive me a stock clerk with a goal and I‚Äôll give you a man who will make history. Give me a man with no goals and I‚Äôll give you a stock clerk.‚Äù ‚Äî J.C. Penney

Asking questions: ‚ÄúQuestions are places in your mind where answers fit. If you haven‚Äôt asked the question, the answer has nowhere to go.‚Äù ‚Äî Clayton Christensen

Being proactive: ‚ÄúDig the well before you are thirsty.‚Äù ‚Äî Ancient proverb

Focus: ‚ÄúThe man who chases two rabbits catches neither.‚Äù ‚Äî Confucius

Failing: ‚ÄúTry and fail but don‚Äôt fail to try‚Äù ‚Äî Stephen Kaggow

Empathy: ‚ÄúTreat others how they want to be treated.‚Äù ‚Äî Dad

Being present: ‚ÄúYesterday is history, tomorrow is a mystery, and today is a gift‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs why they call it present‚Äù ‚Äî Master Oogway

Staying humble: ‚ÄúThe humble man makes room for progress, The proud man believes he is already there.‚Äù ‚Äî Ed Parker

Courage: ‚ÄúAll our dreams can come true, if we have the courage to pursue them.‚Äù ‚Äì Walt Disney

Patience: ‚ÄúIt is easier to find men who will volunteer to die, than to find those who are willing to endure pain with patience.‚Äù ‚Äî Julius Caesar

Listening: ‚ÄúWisdom is the reward you get for a lifetime of listening when you‚Äôd preferred to talk.‚Äù ‚Äî Doug Larson

Storytelling: ‚ÄúGreat stories happen to those who can tell them.‚Äù ‚Äî Ira Glas

Compounding Interest: ‚ÄúCompounding interest is the fifth wonder of the world‚Äù ‚Äî Albert Einstein + ‚ÄúInvestment in knowledge pays the best interest‚Äù ‚Äî Ben Franklin

Inversion: ‚ÄúIt is not enough to think about difficult problems one way. You need to think about them forwards and backward.‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäCharlie Munger

Reflection: ‚ÄúPain plus reflection equals progress‚Äù ‚Äî Ray Dalio
entry.summary: What‚Äôs next?: ‚ÄúFigure out what information, people or resource you need in life to get to the next level.‚Äù - Me Goal setting: ‚ÄúGive me a stock clerk with a goal and I‚Äôll give you a man who will make history. Give me a man with no goals and I‚Äôll give you a stock clerk.‚Äù ‚Äî J.C. Penney

entry.title: Good Markets
entry.content:
According to Marc Andreesen, ‚Äúproduct/market fit means being in a Good Market with a product that can satisfy that market.‚Äù

We know the importance of PMF but what defines a Good Market?

Good markets are big.

Arthur Rock, Fairchild Semiconductor: ‚ÄúGive me a giant market ‚Äî always.‚Äù

Sequoia Capital: A market on the path to a $1B potential allows for error and time for real margins to develop.

Don Valentine, Sequoia Capital: Target big markets - If you don‚Äôt attack a big market, it‚Äôs highly unlikely that you‚Äôre going to build a big company.

Good markets are growing.

Masayoshi Son, SoftBank: And I wanted to pick a business where the business category itself would be growing for the next 30 to 50 years. I didn‚Äôt want to choose a sinking ship.

Marc Andreesen: And the market will range from booming to comatose.

Nicolas Bustamante: The market is growing and so the problem increases.

Good markets are rich and hungry.

Steve Blank: Customer Validation proves that you have found a set of customers and a market who react positively to the product: By relieving those customers of some of their money.

Sequoia Capital: Target customers who will move fast and pay a premium for a unique offering.

Andy Rachleff: ‚ÄúIf you address a market that really wants your product ‚Äî if the dogs are eating the dog food ‚Äî then you can screw up almost everything in the company and you will succeed.

Good markets have existing solutions.

Don Valentine, Sequoia Capital: A lot of successful products are knock offs of products with huge market shares held by companies like Sony (iPod vs. walkman )

Andy Rachleff, CEO Wealthfront: ‚ÄúFirst to market seldom matters. Rather, first to product/market fit is almost always the long-term winner.‚Äù ‚ÄúTime after time, the winner is the first company to deliver the food the dogs want to eat.‚Äù ‚ÄúOnce a company has achieved product market fit, it is extremely difficult to dislodge it, even with a better or less expensive product.‚Äù

Good markets fit their founders.

Paul Graham, YC: The best way to come up with startup ideas is to ask yourself the question: what do you wish someone would make for you?

Masayoshi Son, SoftBank: One success measure was that I should fall in love with a particular business for the next 50 years at least. Very often, people get excited for the first few years, and then, after they see the reality, they get tired of the business. I wanted to choose one that I would feel more and more excited about as the years passed.

Chris Dixon, a16z Crypto: You should fit your market not only because you understand it, but because you love it ‚Äî and will continue to love it as your product and market change over time.
entry.summary: According to Marc Andreesen, ‚Äúproduct/market fit means being in a Good Market with a product that can satisfy that market.‚Äù

entry.title: Two Paths to Product Market Fit

link.title: Two Paths to Product Market Fit

entry.content:
What is product market fit?

‚ÄúProduct/market fit means being in a good market with a product that can satisfy that market.‚Äù -pmarca

‚ÄúIf you address a market that really wants your product ‚Äî if the dogs are eating the dog food ‚Äî then you can screw up almost everything in the company and you will succeed. Conversely, if you‚Äôre really good at execution but the dogs don‚Äôt want to eat the dog food, you have no chance of winning.‚Äù Andy Rachleff

There are two paths to product market fit.

  1. Start with a market. Find a product for the market.

  2. Start with a product. Find a market for the product.

Market First

But too often the focus is on latter part of the sentence (a product that can satisfy the market) and not the former (in a good market). Andreessen emphasizes that market matters most: ‚ÄúYou can obviously screw up a great market ‚Äî and that has been done, and not infrequently ‚Äî but assuming the team is baseline competent and the product is fundamentally acceptable, a great market will tend to equal success and a poor market will tend to equal failure.‚Äù That‚Äôs why time spent building a business around the product alone is pointless: ‚ÄúBest case, it‚Äôs going to be a zombie. ‚Ä¶ in a terrible market, you can have the best product in the world and an absolutely killer team, and it doesn‚Äôt matter‚Ää‚Äì‚Ääyou‚Äôre going to fail. (a16z)

Marc Andreessen writes: ‚ÄúIn a great market ‚Äî a market with lots of real potential customers ‚Äî the market pulls product out of the startup.‚Äù (a16z)

‚ÄúFounders have to choose a market long before they have any idea whether they will reach product/market fit.‚Äù Chris Dixon (cdixon)

Product First

Product 1st, Market 2nd: Most successful new markets begin with a market-sensitive technologist recognizing an inflection point that enables a new kind of product. The next question becomes: ‚Äúwho wants to buy my product?‚Äù Start with the product and search for the market as opposed to vice versa. Evaluating a market trying to find holes and developing solutions for those problems will lead to mundane outcomes. (Medium)

Even though serendipity plays a role here, there is a process ‚Äî which is why Rachleff later created and teaches a course at Stanford, Aligning Startups with their Markets. Steve Blank also developed a customer development process based on the idea that startups should apply the scientific method just like scientists do: start with a hypothesis, test it, prove it, move on or further iterate on the hypothesis. Similarly, Rachleff observes that ‚ÄúFirst you need to define and test your value hypothesis. And then only once proven do you move on to your growth hypothesis. The value hypothesis defines the what, the who, and the how. What are you going to build, who is desperate for it, and what is the business model you are going to use to deliver it?‚Äù Startups should therefore start with the product and try to find the market, as opposed to starting with the market to find the product. It‚Äôs important to emphasize here that the iteration is more about the market and the business model than the product itself. a16z

entry.title: Sunbird Approach - Transporting Proven Models
entry.content:
I recently discovered that Netflix was NOT founded because Blockbuster charged Reed Hastings with a $40 late fee for ‚ÄúApollo 13‚Äù

Instead, the founders wanted to create ‚ÄúThe Amazon of X,‚Äù and settled on DVDs‚Ä¶

This is not a bad thing.

The book Creators‚Äôs Code classifies the Netflix founding story as a Sunbird Approach.

Sunbirds transport solutions that work in one area and apply them to another, often with a twist.

Sunbirds take something that already exists and transport the model to create something new. they relocate and reshape existing concepts across geographies and industries, and bring old ideas up to date.

They examine how and why it worked initially, and what similarities or differences will make it work again.

Here‚Äôs a list of proven models (Amazon of X) that can be transported to other markets.

Proven models to transport:

  • Glossier of X = Content + Commerce
    • playbook
      • grow content & community around an area of life
      • sell stuff and/or services to community
    • examples
      • Goop
      • DrAxe
  • Yeti of X = Direct to Consumer Brand
    • playbook
      • upgrade stale product category
      • create a brand
    • examples
      • Warby Parker
      • Harrys
      • Away
      • Outdoor Voices
  • Houzz of X = Market Network
    • playbook
      • create a network
      • add marketplace/saas functionality
    • examples
      • Honeybook
      • AngelList
  • Salesforce of X = Saas
    • playbook
      • create software in path of revenue or mission critical workflow
      • sell, sell, sell
    • examples
      • Hubspot
      • Pardot
      • Segment
  • Netflix of X = Subscription content
    • playbook
      • create/aggregate content
      • grow subscribers
    • examples
      • Headspace
      • Peloton
      • Blinkist
  • Airbnb of X = Marketplace
    • playbook
      • aggregate suppliers
      • grow GMV
    • examples
      • Breather
      • OYO
  • CarMax of X = Reselling
    • playbook
      • buy asset at a discount
      • sell asset for a profit
    • examples
      • Opendoor
      • E-cycle
  • Red Ventures of X = Lead generation
    • playbook
      • acquire leads (with content or ads)
      • sell leads
    • examples
      • Technology Advice
      • Nerdwallet
entry.summary: I recently discovered that Netflix was NOT founded because Blockbuster charged Reed Hastings with a $40 late fee for ‚ÄúApollo 13‚Äù
